Horizon Imagination improves the imagination efficiency of diffusion-based world models, enabling effective generations with sub-frame budgets and efficient on-policy generation for training lightweight controllers in imagination. 
HI proposes a sampling schedule that improves over the popular Pyramidal schedule (Diffusion Forcing).

This repository contains the training and evaluation code used in the ICLR 2026 paper.




<p align="center">
  <!-- <img src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e9d728b9-223c-4408-a7a1-2aedb9629efd" alt="demo"> -->
  <!-- <img src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f80f2873-429c-4437-af6d-50047b004118" alt="demo"> -->
</p>

<!--
Imagined rollout starting from a few context frames (blue border) with the following baselines:
- Reconstruction: autoencoder only (no world model predictions) reconstruction of the stored context continuation (raplay buffer)
- Fixed: imagination is conditioned on the recorded action sequence from the replay buffer
- Naive: imagination is conditioned on actions from the learned policy with naive action sampling at each denoising step
- Ours: imagination is conditioned on actions from the learned policy with the proposed stable action sampling mechanism

Note: The above videos were geneated using *one* denoising step per frame. The model was trained under a limited interaction budget of just 100K environment steps!
-->

---


## ğŸš€ Quickstart
### Requirements
- ğŸ³ Docker
- ğŸ–¥ï¸ NVIDIA GPU with recent drivers

This project works best with Docker, as it automatically installs complex dependencies such as Craftium on a tested system setup. Running without Docker is possible by following the dockerfile setup steps (Linux only) but requires manual installation of additional dependencies.


---
## ğŸ³ Docker Setup

### Build the image
```bash
docker build -t horizon-imagination .
```

### Run the container
```bash
docker run --gpus all -v .:/horizon_imagination -it horizon-imagination /bin/bash
```
Make sure to run the above command from the project root directory.

---

## ğŸ® Training an Online Agent

Training uses a **clientâ€“server setup**.  
We strongly recommend using `tmux` (or another terminal multiplexer).

### 1ï¸âƒ£ Start the environment server
```bash
portal-env start <env_name> -b mm
```

Supported environments:
- `ale` â€” Atari (ALE)
- `craftium` â€” Craftium (Minecraft-like)

Example:
```bash
portal-env start ale -b mm
```

---

### 2ï¸âƒ£ Launch training (new tmux pane)
```bash
PYTHONPATH=. python experiments/train_agent_online.py \
  -b <env_name> \
  -g <game_id>
```

Example:
```bash
PYTHONPATH=. python experiments/train_agent_online.py \
  -b ale \
  -g ALE/Boxing-v5
```

----


## ğŸ§± Project Structure

```
horizon_imagination/
â”œâ”€â”€ horizon_imagination/   # Core models, imagination logic, training code
â”œâ”€â”€ experiments/           # Training and evaluation entry points
â”œâ”€â”€ config/                # Experiment configurations
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/               # Utilities (setup, analysis, plotting)
â”œâ”€â”€ outputs/               # Local artifacts (logs, checkpoints)
â”œâ”€â”€ results/               # Official results reported in the paper
â”œâ”€â”€ tests/                 # Lightweight sanity checks
â””â”€â”€ README.md
```

## ğŸ§° Common Issues

### ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ”§ Docker file ownership
Docker may change the ownership of the generated output files on some systems. Fix with:
```bash
sudo chown -R 1000:1000 .
```
